fields.title: Dragonriders of Pern
fields.description: Also known as: * Drakenrijders van Pern * Cavaleiros de Pern * Zmajevi jahači Perna * Drakeni z Pernu This series is for the original Pern Trilogy. Note that both in publication and chronological order the first two books of the Harper Hall Trilogy come before The White Dragon. For the full series see: Pern (Publication Order) Pern (Chronological Order) Also consider that reader Trike says "Dragonflight by Anne McCaffrey is a standalone. (It's actually a fix-up novel comprised of her two Pern novellas with additional material added.) The sequels were added later. Numbers 2 and 3, Dragonquest and The White Dragon were written later. A decade later in the case of the latter. The White Dragon can be read as a standalone. (But it's better as the third in the series.)"

fields.title: Heritage of Shannara
fields.description: These books continue the larger Shannara series after The Original Shannara Trilogy. To continue the series past this point, see The Voyage of the Jerle Shannara. Series also known as: *Gli eredi di Shannara

fields.title: Dragonlance: The War of Souls
fields.description: The War of Souls is a war set in the popular Dragonlance fictional universe. The War of Souls series follows the heroes of The War of the Lance to fill in many details of the Dungeons & Dragons fantasy role-playing game storyline. Like many Dragonlance stories, the series can be read as stand alone stories or in series order. [Wikipedia]

fields.title: Book of Ember
fields.description:
A kids' and young adult, science-fiction series. 
    
    Although [book:The Prophet of Yonwood|207034] takes place before [book:The City of Ember|307791], it was published as book 3.
fields.note: This order is listed in publication order, NOT chronological order.

fields.title: Aubrey & Maturin
fields.description: Patrick O'Brian's beloved series of 19th-century British naval fiction.

fields.title: Vlad Taltos
fields.description:
Steven Brust's fantasy series follows Vlad Taltos: a short-statured, short-lived human in an Empire of tall, long-lived Dragaerans. http://us.macmillan.com/series/vlad This is one series set in Steven Brust's Draegaran world. Of the ordering, the author notes:
One of the questions I'm most often asked is: "In what order would you recommend reading these books?" Unfortunately, I'm just exactly the wrong guy to ask. I made every effort to write them so that they could be read in any order. I am aware that, in some measure at least, I have failed (I certainly wouldn't recommend starting with Teckla, for example), but the fact that I was trying makes me incapable of giving an answer. Many people whose opinion I respect believe publication order is best . . . The choice, I daresay, is yours. In any case, I hope you enjoy them. --Steven Brust, 1999, in the notes for The Book of Jhereg
The books are numbered in publication order; here is a rough guide to chronological order: Taltos (1988) Dragon (1998) Yendi (1984) Tiassa, section 1 (2011) Jhereg (1983) Teckla (1987) Phoenix (1990) Jhegaala (2008) Athyra (1993) Orca (1996) Issola (2001) Dzur (2006) Tiassa, section 2 (2011) Iorich (2010) Tiassa, section 3 (2011) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_Brust http://us.macmillan.com/series/Vlad

fields.title: Pellucidar
fields.description: The original series has 7 novels. In 1976, Mahars of Pellucidar was authorized by the Burroughs estate and published as a sequel to the novels.
